head.title: Founder of Corel Resigns From Chief Executive Post

hedline.hl1: Founder of Corel Resigns From Chief Executive Post

abstract.p: Michael Cowpland, founder of Corel Corp, abruptly resigns from all his executive positions and puts company's future in hands of new chief executive and revamped board; will remain a director; Cowpland is succeeded as interim chief executive and president by Derek J Burney; James Baillie takes over as chairman and will head committee to review composition of board and Corel's survival plan (M)

block.p: Michael Cowpland, the founder of the Corel Corporation, abruptly resigned today from all his executive positions at the ailing Canadian software developer, and put its future in the hands of a new chief executive and a revamped board. He said he would remain a director.

Mr. Cowpland is succeeded as interim chief executive and president by Derek J. Burney, formerly Corel's executive vice president for engineering and chief of technology. James Baillie, a well-known Toronto lawyer, has taken over as chairman of Corel and will head a committee to review the composition of the board and Corel's survival plan.

Michael Cowpland, the founder of the Corel Corporation, abruptly resigned today from all his executive positions at the ailing Canadian software developer, and put its future in the hands of a new chief executive and a revamped board. He said he would remain a director.

Mr. Cowpland is succeeded as interim chief executive and president by Derek J. Burney, formerly Corel's executive vice president for engineering and chief of technology. James Baillie, a well-known Toronto lawyer, has taken over as chairman of Corel and will head a committee to review the composition of the board and Corel's survival plan.

The British-born Mr. Cowpland, 57, started Corel 15 years ago after he and a partner, Terence Matthews, sold their interest in a telecommunications equipment maker, the Mitel Corporation. Corel developed computer software products like Coreldraw and acquired others, like Wordperfect, and its stock traded as high as $44.50 on the Nasdaq in 1999. But investor confidence collapsed as the company continued to lose money and failed to meet promised profit forecasts. Today, its shares closed at $3.66, up 6.25 cents.

With sales of its older graphics design products in decline, Corel tied its future to the Linux operating system, but the collapse of a merger earlier this year with the Inprise Corporation left it short of cash. In June, 350 jobs were cut -- 21 percent of the staff -- as part of a plan to trim costs by $40 million a year.
Mr. Cowpland, who owns about 10 percent of Corel and recently said he expects the company to be profitable by the fourth quarter, said he would pursue start-up opportunities.

Also, he is likely to be tried later this year on charges of insider trading, brought by the Ontario Securities Commission last fall, for selling $14 million worth of shares in 1997 shortly before unexpectedly poor earnings were reported.
